chapter.title: Introduction to Quoddy
chapter.para: Quoddy is an Open Source Enterprise Social Network, which shares common "look and feel" elements, and substantial functionality, with consumer facing Social Networks like Facebook or Google+ as well as proprietary Enterprise Social Network products like the products from Jive Software and Yammer among others. But unlike consumer Social Networks, Quoddy is intended for organizational use and therefore has capabilities which make it uniquely suited to provide the social fabric to support organizational knowledge sharing, knowledge transfer, collaboration and decision support.

section.title: The Activity Stream
section.para: The Activity Stream is the central element of the Quoddy interface. The Activity Stream takes up the right hand side of the main page in Quoddy, and displays Status Updates from other users, Business Events from backend systems, Calendar Events from calendaring / groupware systems, User Tasks from BPM / workflow systems, User activity events from external systems, Document links from Document Management Systems, and other events of interest to you, based on the users you friend/follow, groups you join, and the subscriptions you define.

Since Users do not necessarily want to see all content all the time, Quoddy has a concept known as Stream Definitions. A User creates a Stream Definition to collect a related group of Users, User Lists, Groups and Subscriptions, and batch that content together. When a User has multiple Stream Definitions, a simple dropdown menu allows the User to toggle which collection is rendered into the main Activity Stream at any given time.

section.title: Friends & Followers
section.para: Adding another User as a "Friend" requires that User's approval and creates a two way connection between the two users. Following a user creates a one-way connection and does not require approval from the user being followed.

By default, your will be include Status Updates from users who you have Friended or Followed. In turn, Friended users, or users who Follow you, will receive your Status Updates by default. However, configurable User Stream definitions in Quoddy allow you to fine tune your Activity Stream at a finer level of detail, to ensure that you receive exactly the information you need, and no more.

section.title: User Lists & Groups
section.para: User Lists allow a User to group related people together, and quickly filter their Activity Stream down to only updates from those Users. A User can have multiple such groups, and a simple dropdown menu allows the User to select the active User List at any time.

Groups support multi-user collaboration around a given topic, interest, project, or other unifying concept. Users may search for Groups which are of interest to them, join those Groups, and then share content with, and recieve status updates from, those Groups. A User may join many Groups, and a simple dropdown menu allows the User to select which Group's content they wish to view at any given time.

chapter.section:
Subscriptions
Perhaps the most powerful and important feature in Quoddy, subscriptions allow Users to register interest in various kinds of content from both within their organization, and from outside the organiation, and then have that content delivered straight to their Activity Stream.
Quoddy currently supports four types of Subscriptions:
Activiti User Tasks
Business Events
Calendar Feeds
RSS Feed Subscription
For more information on configuring Subscriptions please see the chapter.

section.title: Basics
section.para: Your Activity Stream will normally look something like the image below, filled with a variety of different types of content, including a mix of Status Updates from Friends, Calendar Events, Business Events and RSS Feed Items from Subscriptions, etc.

The Activity Stream area allows you to operate on this content in various ways, including:
Commenting
Voting
Sharing

Commenting provides a means to annotate content items with your personal observations, thoughts or insights, and to reply to similar comments from other users. These discussions around a piece of content, such as a report from the Business Intelligence group, a Business Event, or other relevant enterprise content, facilitate the generation, capture and reuse of valuable knowledge and can directly lead to better decision making, increased productivity and crucial innovations.

To interact with the Comments on an item in your stream, simply click "Show Comments" to show any existing comments, or click inside the textbox labeled "Add a Comment" to leave your own comment. To temporarily hide the comments associated with an item, click the "Hide Comments" link.

To "Share" an item with another user, simply click the "Share" link near the bottom of the entry. To add a comment to the newly shared item, add your comment text in the uppermost textbox of the resulting dialog. Type the username of the user you are sharing the item with in the lower textbox and click "Submit" to complete the action. Shared items will appear in the Activity Stream of the user you share with.

(This feature is not yet implemented) To Vote (or "+1") an item in your stream, simply click the "+1" link at the bottom of the item, near the Comments area. The current "score" of an item will reflect the number of users who have voted for it. Voting also marks an item as being of interest to you, and - in future versions of Quoddy - will be factored into algorithms which automatically recommend content for you. Future versions will also support the ability to quickly access the list of items that you have voted for, and the ability to remove an existing vote.

section.title: User Stream Definitions
section.para: In order to provider users with fine-grained control over exactly which content appears in their Activity Stream, Quoddy supports the creation and user of user defined "Stream" entries which define a collection of requested content items by type, user, group, list, or subscription. You may, for example, define a "Stream" which only includes Business Events and nothing else. Or, you may define a Stream which includes content from three specifically designated users, plus events from a specific Calendar Feed, and Business Events from one specified Business Event Subscription. You may mix and match and tailor these definitions to fit your exact criteria.

The default Stream entry includes all content from all uses that you have friended or followed, as well as content from any Group you join, and all Subscriptions you create. It is not recommended to modify the default Stream definition, but rather to create new definitions to suit your requirements. The currently active Stream definition can be easily changed by selecting it from the "Streams" dropdown menu above the Activity Stream area.

To continue creating your new Stream definition, click the big blue "Create a New Stream" button, which begins the New Stream Wizard. The first page of the wizard will appear something like the image below:
Enter a name and a description for your new Stream, and click "Next" to proceed to the next page of the New Stream Wizard. The second page will appear something like the image below:

Select the types of content you wish to appear in your new stream (Ctrl+Click to select multiple items) and click "Next" to go to the next page of the New Stream Wizard. The third page will appear something like the image below:
Select the users whose updates you wish to appear in your new stream and click "Next" to go to the next page of the New Stream Wizard. The fourth page will appear something like the image below:

Select the User Lists that contain users whose updates you wish to appear in your new stream and click "Next" to go to the next page of the New Stream Wizard. The fifth page will appear something like the image below:
Select the Groups whose updates you wish to appear in your new stream and click "Next" to go to the next page of the New Stream Wizard. The sixth page will appear something like the image below:

Select the Subscriptions whose content you wish to appear in your new stream and click "Finish" to complete the New Stream Wizard. This will return you to the "Manage Streams" page, and you will see your new Stream listed along with the others.

section.title: Basics
section.para: Your user profile is where you describe yourself, list your interests, skills, past projects, and other biographical information. Sharing profile information helps people find each other when they need information, expertise or tacit knowledge, or just want to socialize and engage with their colleagues to build comradery and mutual trust and connection.
